It's no secret that Batman has quite a few movies under his utility belt, but there's one core aspect of his character that's rarely been shown on the big screen: his detective skills. He is known as the "World's Greatest Detective" after all, yet in most of his films, we don't see him do much investigating… until now. More so than a traditional comic book movie, ‘The Batman', from director/producer/co-writer Matt Reeves, is a detective story, a refreshing change of pace from the character's previous live-action installments. In the film, Gotham City's elite and "upstanding" citizens become the targets of a mysterious serial killer called the Riddler, and Batman (two years into his crime-fighting crusade), along with GCPD Lieutenant Jim Gordon, must solve his clues in order to put an end to the bloodshed, all the while uncovering corruption and lies kept hidden by the city's rich and powerful. Along the way, they encounter an intriguing cast of characters, including unlikely ally Selina Kyle, crime boss Carmine Falcone, and Oswald "Oz" Cobblepot aka the Penguin, Falcone's lieutenant and proprietor of the Iceberg Lounge nightclub. Every single member of the cast is incredible, with many of them becoming my personal favorite live-action adaptations of their respective character, such as Robert Pattinson's titular Dark Knight, who exudes a quiet intensity and is able to convey a multitude of emotions without speaking a word, and Colin Farrell's Penguin, who is utterly unrecognizable in the role and steals every scene he's in, to name a few. The film itself is captivating and incredibly well-paced despite having a nearly 3-hour runtime, and my eyes were glued to the screen throughout the entirety of it. One reason for this is the fact that ‘The Batman' is easily the most beautifully-shot comic book movie I've ever seen, due to the exceptionally brilliant work of cinematographer Greig Fraser. I also have to give major praise to composer Michael Giacchino and production designer James Chinlund, whose music and sets elevated the film to a whole new level and filled me with excitement, suspense, and many more emotions. Overall, Matt Reeves and co. have proven that they truly understand the characters they're working with and have crafted a smart, gripping masterpiece set in a new Bat-universe which I'm incredibly eager to revisit as soon as possible and will hopefully continue for many years to come.

On first viewing, in the theater, I thought The Batman to be loud, long, and somewhat slow-paced. I found the slow motion scenes to be overly used and detracting from the story. I didn't love Andy Serkis as Alfred. Pattinson, though he had impressed me in his post-glampire appearances, was far from my first choices to don the cape. And DC has dropped one steaming turd after another in the past decade and a half as if a team of caffeinated tweens were running the entire WBfilm studios. 

But ultimately I dismissed these as minor gripes, ate my popcorn, and somewhat enjoyed a sunday movie which I intended on quickly forgetting. 

But I didn't forget it. I thought about...a lot. It bugged me that I liked it more than I wanted to, and I wanted to hate it. I got on YouTube to seek out scathing video reviews to help me feel better about wanting to hate it, there's PLENTY on there.  Which is when I happened on a YouTube video posted by the channel: Macabre Storytelling called "Why The Batman is NOT a Batman Film". ( https://youtu.be/tyRnkwo4Pds ) and it completely changed my mind. It gave such a fresh perspective that, in my haste to hate, had originally gone well over my head. After viewing the movie a second time, this time through the lens of perspective given by the video, I see The Batman as arguably the best Batman Film to date. 

That slow pacing and those slo-mo shots no longer irked me. They drew me in to the emotional weight of the story, allowing me to soak in the surrounding atmosphere. Permitting me to experience a quiet moment in an otherwise chaotic City. Seeing Batman where he is between the angry kid from origin tales and the polished veteran crimefighter of later years...seeing him as a still confused young man in his coming of age tale, processing the results of his actions and seeing that he is a small part of the bigger picture...really resonated in a way that no other batman Film has done before. He had the power, but hadn't yet figured out the responsibility. He isn't Batman yet, he is just raw, and mostly blind, if not at least tone deaf "vengeance". 

Paul Dano's Riddler was chilling, haunting, and such a refreshing take on a character that has been too often cast as comic relief. Pattinson shined in a role where the one-dimensionality of the character is intentional. The real test will be in the (hopeful) sequel where he'll have the chance to spread his acting wings and we'll see his diversity as Batwayne. Zoe is a very strong actress, she shines here. I have always been obsessed with Batman from an early age as I have watched the animated series, the Justice League series, Lego Batman and other Batman media content. As I grew up, I stopped watching Batman related media for a while until this movie released. Directed by Matt Reeves, The Batman 2022 is a reboot from the previous Batman films and this time, this movie depicts a more realistic Gotham city with a dark, noir and  detective style story of Batman who takes on the job of protecting Gotham city and when I mean by realistic, there are no superpowers and superhuman beings at all. Realistic scenarios, realistic hand to hand combat scenes, vehicles and the list could go on. This movie is very different from your usual action packed superhero films like the movies  Marvel would usually make. So, I suggest you turn back if you are one of those superhero movie fans that cares about action scenes and superpowers because you are going to witness something different.
    The film itself is aesthetically pleasing and I mean it for the entire movie which I will explain more about later in this review.
   The story takes place 2 years after The Batman publicized himself to Gotham city, a city with filled with corruption and crime. While keeping a lookout for the city, a serial killer named Riddler emerges and starts killing influential figures of Gotham city, whom all have  corrupt connections to each other and also leaving clues that leads up to an even greater conspiracy. Batman must solve all these mysteries and riddles in order to find out who the next target is, solve the conspiracy and put an end to the Riddler. Does he have what it takes to stop the Riddler?
Robert Pattinson nails the role as Batman: a depressed and edgy caped crusader (this is what most people like to call him) who is scarred by the death of his parents 20 years ago caused by a group of criminals. He was able to capture the vibe of a dark and depressed person that Batman is: Does not talk much, blunt and an intimidating vigilante that the Batman is known for. He also played the other side of Batman as well, Bruce Wayne. When Bruce is not under his mask and suit, he is just a depressed billionaire who owns the Wayne enterprise and deals with public affairs and still as edgy as Batman. Robert Pattison was able to portray both Bruce Wayne and Batman very well. You can just look into his eyes and feel that dark and gloomy vibe.
 Supporting roles like the Cat woman (Zoey was spot on with the sassy attitude) and commissioner police Gordon were also done very well as they were able to show how it is like to partner up with Batman, who is stubborn, quiet and straightforward. Paul Dano as the Riddler was immaculate as he managed to play as a menacing and mentally deranged person who is just a normal human being that can cause disruption and violence in Gotham city. He showed off his performance even furthermore in the scene where he talks with Batman in Arkham Asylum.  Colin Farrell also brought the character Penguin to life with the accent and the personality which was spot on like the comics. The same exact thing could be said for the actor who played the crime boss Carmine Falcone. All the actors managed to bring the characters to life just by the way they talked in the movie. You could even feel the tension during the characters' conversations.

  Cinematography in this movie is top tier. Some will think the camera work is too much, but I think that doing too much is what made the film beautiful. The still shots of Gotham city from different perspectives, still shots of the characters, the shots of Batman looking over Gotham city, the dark color palate used and especially the lighting the movies uses, it makes the film look and feel dark. The fight scenes' fast paced camera work was executed properly as it perfectly choreographed all the fighting moves and the camera follows the Batman while he performs all these fighting techniques making us feel the intense action.
The scene where Batman revs up his Bat mobile in the dark and reveals himself was one of the best cameras work, I have seen in my life. The way the engine lights up showing the flames, the full view of the Batmobile from all perspective, the terrifying engine sounds the Batmobile makes, it's just top tier. That moment was pure hype fuel.  I could feel that intimidating appearance of the Batmobile. The movie felt immersive due to its excellent camera work and cinematography.
   The music and soundtrack used was a perfect fit for the impressive cinematography as the music enhanced every moment in the movie. Every fight scene and chase scenes felt intense due to the fitting soundtrack. You could even feel the tension between the characters conversations.
 However, the length of the movie felt unnecessary in my opinion. Sure, all the scenes were pretty, but some scenes could be cut out as it felt like it, they were not necessary for the movie's plot. With that time, they could have explored more areas of Gotham city or show more characters. Other than that, the movie is superb.
   Overall, this Batman movie is a dark, gritty and realistic take on Batman and Gotham city with a fascinating psychological thriller story that will keep you asking many questions while watching the film. This film will not be for those who enjoy action packed superhero films as this movie have dark and depressing themes and the long length of the film might scare some people away. But try it out, see if you like it or not. I would recommend this movie to every Batman fans though. 4/5 stars movie and very excited for a sequel.

‘Planet of the Apes' writer/director Matt Reeves directs Robert Pattinson in this stylish reboot of the caped crusader. Pattinson leads an A-list cast that includes Zoë Kravitz, Jeffrey Wright, Colin Farrell, Paul Dano and Andy Serkis. Reeves delivers a masterclass in filmmaking, bringing a dark, gritty adaptation of Batman to the screen that leaves you wanting more as soon as the credits roll.

When The Riddler (Paul Dano) begins his killing spree, targeting Gotham City's key political figures, billionaire Bruce Wayne is called into action donning the iconic cowl as he begins to investigate. As Bruce explores the deep-rooted corruption hidden behind some of Gotham's most well-known figures, the full scale of the sadistic serial killer's plan comes to light, forcing Bruce to question his past as he tries to save the city of Gotham and its people.

‘Dune' cinematographer Greig Fraser adds to his stellar streak of work, providing ‘The Batman' with sensational cinematography, creating a gothic feast for the eyes while also capturing the dark underbelly of Gotham City. Fraser's visuals allow for this film to be not only a visual spectacle, but also a thoroughly entertaining film. Much like James Mangold's ‘Logan' or Christopher Nolan's Dark Knight Trilogy, ‘The Batman' positions itself as one of the darker superhero adaptations – both thematically and narratively, as well as visually. Acclaimed composer Michael Giacchino crafts a magnificent score for the film, creating an addictive mix of booming orchestral pieces and eerie choir pieces. Giacchino's new theme for the caped crusader, an intense and thundering piece of music will arguably go on to define the character for years to come.

Despite the hefty near three-hour run-time, Matt Reeves ensures that audiences are kept on the edges of their seats and entertained throughout. Robert Pattinson slips effortlessly into the role as the iconic hero, giving a marvellous performance as an intimidating hero, and mysterious billionaire. Pattinson's performance leaves you eagerly anticipating for when the ‘Twilight' star next dons the emblematic cowl, with a portrayal that manages to capture Batman's humanity so easily and subtlety.

Paul Dano arguably gives the best performance of the film; crafting himself into a terrifying villain, lighting up every second of screen-time he gets. Dano and Pattinson's performances are accompanied by a slick turn as Selina Kyle/Catwoman from ‘Big Little Lies' star Zoë Kravitz, who gives a brilliant performance as the feline anti-hero. However, Colin Farrell's unrecognisable turn ‘The Penguin' can't help but feel like an unnecessary addition to the plot, coming off as a character who's only reason for being included was to set up the character's own HBO Max miniseries currently in the works.

Despite being one of the best films of 2022 so far, ‘The Batman' can't help but suffer from a few issues, including a disjointed third act that ultimately wins you over with a nail-biting final sequence and certain . Matt Reeves threads together a wide web of themes in ‘The Batman' ranging from justice, corruption, to crime and greed. These complex themes come together to create a cryptic, intricate, and multi-layered story that keeps you on your toes, constantly guessing these character's next moves. ‘Planet of the Apes' production designer James Chinlund and ‘Spencer' costume designer Jacqueline Durran bring their respective talents together to create an immersive world that draws you into the crime-ridden streets of Gotham.

Matt Reeves puts his spin on the iconic hero with Warner Bros. latest edition to their plethora of DC films. Driven by a cast that give marvellous performances throughout the three-hour run-time, ‘The Batman' presents a much darker and mysterious version of the well-loved hero to audiences, inviting them to try and solve The Riddler's mystery alongside Bruce Wayne. The film does a stellar job of not only establishing new versions of these characters, but also sets up the future of Robert Pattinson's turn as Batman. Teasing new villains and exciting returns, ‘The Batman' is sure to be a film that audiences will absolutely enjoy, whether you're a DC fan or not.

The Batman does more right than wrong, but it's a touch overindulgent at very nearly 3 hours. This film, as anticipated, serves as a sort of showcase for an upcoming series of films, introducing several noteworthy names throughout the first chunk of the film. Catwoman, Penguin, The Riddler, and that's to say nothing of the less flashy but just as crucial Alfred Pennyworth or the Police Lieutenant, not-yet-Commissioner Jim Gordon. More characters work than do not, but it would have been nice to see a little development, especially for Paul Dano's transfixing take on The Riddler. Completely unhinged, but also calculating Dano's work as the deeply disturbed Edward deserved more screen time without his strange and haunting mask. This Riddler is nothing like the ones you've seen before, and Dano's take is certainly the best Batman villain since Heath Ledger's infamous offering. By the film's conclusion they do give him a backstory, but it's done in a real "fly by" sort of way. The backstory itself is nice and cookie-cuter neat so that it fits in the small window of time allotted for it. Ultimately it doesn't do the film's best character justice, but the performance is still commendable regardless. As for the rest of the cast, they do a fine job - no major complaints, but the film certainly does it's utmost to keep Batman onscreen by keeping Bruce Wayne off of it. While Pattinson does fine behind the cowl, his Bruce Wayne leaves something to be desired. Perhaps the most complete character in the film is Gotham itself. Here the backdrops are all dirty and unkempt, strewn with litter and soot. It rains more often than not here, casting the entirety of the city in a looming hopelessness that's almost palpable. It serves as a constant reminder of the mindset of the people who live there, surrounded by crime and wealthy exuberance, unsafe and too poor to combat the obvious corruption within Gotham's inner workings. This is perhaps best exemplified by John Turturro's transfixing take on Carmine Falcone, a well-known mob boss in Gotham city. Turturro, like Dano, doesn't get the screen time he deserves, but manages to do a lot with the limited time that he is allowed. The story represents a more detective-based approach that was often lacking a certain authenticity in Nolan's trilogy, which is quite welcome overall and it fills the lengthy runtime fairly well as The Riddler leads Batman all over Gotham chasing clues while playing a "Saw-like" game. Overall the package is entertaining enough to recommend, even if one has to clear an entire afternoon or evening to digest it all and the setup at the very end of the movie promises a sequel that could live up to the well-rounded entry we have here.

The themes (of class, wealth, inequality and PTSD) that The Batman delves into are handled carefully.

A good story, direction, cinematography and action choreography would be nothing if the cast isn't brilliant, and the cast of The Batman is nothing short of brilliance. The broody and contemplative Batman is balanced with a flirty and sensual Catwoman, and the villain in the Riddler is malign, twisted and sinister.

The Batman is a riveting start at Matt Reeves and Robert Pattinson's iteration of the titular character, and should leave audiences wanting more from this Batman.

There is no better way than to start 2023 than listening to Robert Pattinson mumble something about fear and vengeance to nobody at all again. Possibly the darkest interpretation of Batman we've ever had, and I don't think anybody is complaining. Matt Reeves takes inspiration from basically any David Fincher film you could think of to create a gripping and intense film that explores Gotham in a new way. Instead of creating an ultra-realistic city, like Christopher Nolan, or an ultra-cartoonish city like Tim Burton, Mett Reeves builds a dark and grim city - much like something out of Se7en. The Batman tears almost every layer of cartoonish fun away, and replaces it with psychological thriller and crime noir. And it pulls it off in magnificent fashion. While Pattinson's Bruce Wayne is not on the level of Christian Bale, his Batman strives to new lengths and achieves something nobody else could have done. His sombre and brooding performance as Batman stands out in a film full to the brim of outstanding performances.

The soundtrack adds to the moodiness of this film, with Nirvana's "Something In The Way" seemingly now the theme song of Gotham. It's hard to decide whether the use of that song is as good as the score though. We've always known Michael Giacchino is a master in his craft, but I have a feeling this could later become known as his magnum opus. An absolute robbery from the academy by the way. As I've said before, it's to decide whether this is actually better than The Dark Knight, but even if it isn't as good, it absolutely comes as close as anything else. The costumes and makeup department had their work cut out here, but they certainly delivered. The mix of CGI and practical effects absolutely works here, and I'm sure this will hold up many years from now. Despite being a new take on batman, this really is faithful to the comic books, bringing us the detective batman in a fresh light. Although this is set at the start of batman's career, it's not an origin story. As much as I like origin stories, this excels because Matt Reeves knows and accepts the people watching this as not stupid. No need to have flashbacks to Wayne's parents death - he knows that we already know what happened. The prime example of this is in one of the first scenes, when Batman is investigating a crime scene and he sees the son of the victim. All we needed was a sorrowful look and we understood his feelings.

Verdict: 🏆 97%

An ambitious film that captures its goal of a gritty, ultra realistic, crime thriller version of Batman. It is enjoyable largely because of this unique vision. 

The Batman shares more in common with the contemporary urban crime style of Frank Miller's "Year One," and less in common with the popcorn action realism of Nolan's Dark Knight trilogy. Yet with this film, we are miles and miles away from Tim Burton's goofy, gothic iteration of the iconic caped crusader. And perhaps that's where this movie falters. It is a little bit too committed to its tone. It is all darkness, without a speck of light. And while that ambition is respectable, ultimately it lacks the much needed levity of Burton and Nolan's films. 

The character development of the titular hero is also severely lacking. We find out little about him at all, other than the fact that he is like a My Chemical Romance version of Bruce Wayne and a very inexperienced, more vulnerable presentation of the character we know and love.

Paul Dano absolutely crushes this uncharacteristically frightening take on The Riddler. 

And the movie is far too long and meandering. 

So it is an ambitious, respectable start but it is seriously flawed and a little too committed to its crushingly macabre atmosphere.
